Trial_Design.evidence: A randomized noninferiority clinical trial enrolled patients undergoing bariatric surgery from May 1, 2015, to June 30, 2016.

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery from May 1, 2015, to June 30, 2016.

Intervention.evidence: The controls received the standard of care with IS use 10 times every hour while awake. The test group did not receive an IS device or these orders.

Objective.evidence: To determine the effect of postoperative IS on hypoxemia, arterial oxygen saturation (Sa o 2 ) level, and pulmonary complications after bariatric surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was frequency of hypoxemia, defined as an Sa o 2 level of less than 92% without supplementation at 6, 12, and 24 postoperative hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomized to postoperative IS (control group) or clinical observation (test group)

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 224 patients (50 men [22.3%] and 174 women [77.7%]; mean [SD] age, 45.6 [11.8] years) were enrolled, and 112 were randomized for each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was based on the evaluable population.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences in frequency of postoperative hypoxemia between the control and test groups were found at 6 (11.9% vs 10.4%; P = .72), 12 (5.4% vs 8.2%; P = .40), or 24 (3.7% vs 4.6%; P = .73) postoperative hours.

Harms.evidence: Rates of 30-day postoperative pulmonary complications did not differ between groups (8 patients [7.1%] in the control group vs 4 [3.6%] in the test group; P = .24).
